This is Graham Hovey, recording in Rome a Letter fr-ra Italy for the network of the
national Association of Educational Broadcasters. These programs are produoed with the
cooperation of Radiotelevision© Italians.
This particular Letter from Italy is designed to coincide, as far as possible, with
the official visit to the United States of the Italian prime minister and foreign minister.
There will he plenty of information available — In the press and on radio and television
—. about the objectives of that visit and what develops from it. But I thought it might
be a good idea to devote this program to a look at the men themselves, and the policies
they have stood for in Italian government and politics.
Both Premier Mario Soelba and Foreign Minister Gaetano Martino are Sicilians, and
they are approximately the same age. There is a temptation to say that any resemblance
between the two men ends at that point. This would not be entirely accurate, as will be
clear in a few minutes. But in appearance, personality, professional background and
political party preference, it is true, the two men are quite dissimilar.
Many of you pwobably could identify Scelba*s picture, if you saw it in your news¬
paper. He has been in the thick of public life almost constantly in post-World War II
years, much of the time as minister of the interior in cabinets of the late Aloide Be
Gaspori. He is short, stocky and bald, with a broad, oval face, prominent nose, and
sharp, widely-set eyes.
If Scelba looks the part of the politician — and many believe he does — Gaetano
Martino seems perfectly cast as foreign minister, so far as appearance is concerned. Re
is a man of only medium height, but he carries himself in a manner that seems just a bit
austere — in the best tradition of the diplomat. He looks younger than his 54 years,
but his grey hair adds just the right touch of maturity to his distinguished bearing.
Scelba*s ingenuous smile is that of the public man. Martino smiles as often as
Scelba, but it seems a bit forced? again, the word "austere" comes to mind.
If Soelba locks the part of the politician, it may be in cart because he has always
been a politician, from the time when, as a boy, he sat at the feet of the famous Sicilian
priest, Bon Luigi sturzo, and got his first political schooling.
Martino*s background was very different. He entered active politics only after World
War II. Prior to that, he was a university professor and a scholar with more then a
hundred published works.
Mario Scelba was bora Sept. 5, 1901, at Caltagirone, in the interior of Sicily, just
nine months after the birth of Gaetano Martino in Messina, not far away.
Caltagirone was also the birthplace of Bon Sturzo, who, in fact, served as mayor of
that city from 1905 to 1920. As a boy, Scelba studied classics with Bon Sturzo in the
classroom and politics outside. The priest-politician founded Italy*s Popular party —
the forerunner of today’s Christian Democratic party — in 1919, which was about the time
young Scelba cam© to Rome to study law.
Soon Scelba was serving as Sturzo*s personal secretary in the Popular party. As
fascism tightened its grip on Italy, Bon Sturzo was obliged to go into exile, but Scelba
continued his political activity a© a journalist for Popular party newspapers until
Mussolini suppressed the anti-fascist parties and press.
